{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3599786,"name":"Jacob Waiser ","username":"Jow5119","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jow5119/{size}/254314_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T12:55:19.103Z","cooked":"

Hello,

I have recently been elected as my team’s new mechanical lead and I was hoping to find a comprehensive but small manufacturing challenge that will give my current members a refresher on all of our most used tools. My team often uses a miter saw, band saw, drill press/ drill, lathe, taps, and obviously wrenches and screwdrivers. if anyone has any suggestions or anything their team does it would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-04-23T04:15:49.408Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":17,"reads":415,"readers_count":414,"score":228.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":500132,"topic_slug":"mechancal-training-ideas","display_username":"Jacob Waiser ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":3,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62712,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5119 Driver & Mech Lead"},"post_url":"/t/mechancal-training-ideas/500132/1","custom_user_title":"5119 Driver & Mech Lead","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3599792,"name":"Andrew","username":"Androo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/androo/{size}/270986_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T12:57:13.843Z","cooked":"

I’m not sure if you are able to with your current schedule and the start of AP tests coming up, but my team is trying to implement an L1 only ground intake onto an extra drive train that we have. If you have space with your algae shooter, I think that would be a fun mechanical challenge to implement!

To be honest idea wise I like that but with our current resources and our plans for later in the off-season id like to make it one or a few smaller projects that don’t involve our robot or building a new robot. we might be doing something similar to that later in our off-season but probably not right now. I will absolutely keep that in the back of my mind though. Thanks!

Just to clarify our offseason plans are to have design CAD an entire robot for a past game that caters to mechanisms we haven’t built in a while and then have mechanical build some of them for practice.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T13:11:02.344Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":335,"readers_count":334,"score":72.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":500132,"topic_slug":"mechancal-training-ideas","display_username":"Jacob Waiser ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62712,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5119 Driver & Mech Lead"},"post_url":"/t/mechancal-training-ideas/500132/5","custom_user_title":"5119 Driver & Mech Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3599838,"name":"","username":"trashgoblin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/trashgoblin/{size}/234495_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T13:28:26.221Z","cooked":"

Honestly this is what I would recommend doing. I am assuming that you have made an elevator because of this year’s game (if not that is an incredibly important subsystem to practice). Otherwise, maybe do a beefy pivot to put your elevator on based on 2023, good project for an add-on to a subsystem you know how to do. Especially considering the extending pivoting arm is such an incredibly powerful archetype.

actually this was our robot this year and we in the end didn’t even include the telescoping arm on the back so some sort of cascading elevator/ chain elevator is definitely on our offseason list. (we built telescoping arms 3 years in a row now) However with your mention of the pivot for an elevator or a pivot in general that is something we have had trouble with making robust in the past so if you have any suggestions for that too it would be greatly appreciated!

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T13:37:46.384Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":255,"readers_count":254,"score":66.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":500132,"topic_slug":"mechancal-training-ideas","display_username":"Jacob Waiser ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":62712,"username":"Jow5119","name":"Jacob Waiser ","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jow5119/{size}/254314_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62712,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5119 Driver & Mech Lead"},"post_url":"/t/mechancal-training-ideas/500132/8","custom_user_title":"5119 Driver & Mech Lead","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3599851,"name":"","username":"trashgoblin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/trashgoblin/{size}/234495_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T13:44:04.241Z","cooked":"

algae shooter my beloved, that’s actually a fire robot.
I think that there are a lot of good pivoting elevators seen in 2023 as an incredibly powerful archetype (148, 6329, etc.) but to be honest, if you are already good at telescopes you probably won’t need it. Learn to make a chonky pivot and do something like a 2910 arm, only adding one subsystem and you get to make easily one of the most competitive archetypes in recent memory. I might learn to do a telescope with chain/string cascade rigging like 2910 and 359 do instead of just string, but if you just use string it would probably be fine. Do what you are comfortable with, and a telescope can serve almost the same purpose as an elevator. If you want to learn how to make a robust pivot I highly recommend this page on FRCDesign 2910 Dead Axle Pivot | FRCDesign.org

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T13:45:48.134Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":238,"readers_count":237,"score":67.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":500132,"topic_slug":"mechancal-training-ideas","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.frcdesign.org/mechanism-examples/pivots/2910_2023_pivot/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"2910 Dead Axle Pivot | FRCDesign.org","clicks":14}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":62712,"username":"Jow5119","name":"Jacob Waiser ","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jow5119/{size}/254314_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65476,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"patrick | cascade crusader"},"post_url":"/t/mechancal-training-ideas/500132/9","custom_user_title":"patrick | cascade crusader","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3599859,"name":"Jacob Waiser ","username":"Jow5119","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jow5119/{size}/254314_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T13:49:55.019Z","cooked":"

we do find stability issues in our telescoping arm so something chain based or string based may be significantly better but I would also still like have the larger chain based elevator down especially with the prospect of larger recycle rush like game pieces in the future.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T13:50:16.391Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":214,"readers_count":213,"score":42.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":500132,"topic_slug":"mechancal-training-ideas","display_username":"Jacob Waiser ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":65476,"username":"trashgoblin","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/trashgoblin/{size}/234495_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62712,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5119 Driver & Mech Lead"},"post_url":"/t/mechancal-training-ideas/500132/10","custom_user_title":"5119 Driver & Mech Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600240,"name":"Jacob Waiser ","username":"Jow5119","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jow5119/{size}/254314_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T17:36:45.466Z","cooked":"

An example of the type of project I’m looking for is actually something from my rookie year where our leads had us make these little clamps from a c-channel and a bolt by cutting it down and then drilling and tapping a hole in the top and then we analyzed their accuracy in size and straightness of tap. it was small simple and a good refresher on those few tools however id like a little complexity and more tools involved.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T17:36:45.466Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":164,"readers_count":163,"score":32.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":500132,"topic_slug":"mechancal-training-ideas","display_username":"Jacob Waiser ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62712,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5119 Driver & Mech Lead"},"post_url":"/t/mechancal-training-ideas/500132/11","custom_user_title":"5119 Driver & Mech Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3683462,"name":"Jacob Waiser ","username":"Jow5119","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jow5119/{size}/254314_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-18T05:08:37.486Z","cooked":"

Okay, now that we are further into off-season and approaching recruitment season i have a new question to ask. I’m currently constructing the curriculum to train our new members with when they arrive in September(ish) and I’m once again having trouble thinking of projects and other ways to make sure that not only our rookies are excited about the season (and hopefully the coming years) but also are well prepared for build season when it arrives. If anyone has any suggestions that would be greatly appreciated!

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-07-18T05:08:37.486Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":109,"readers_count":108,"score":31.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":500132,"topic_slug":"mechancal-training-ideas","display_username":"Jacob Waiser ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62712,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5119 Driver & Mech Lead"},"post_url":"/t/mechancal-training-ideas/500132/12","custom_user_title":"5119 Driver & Mech Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3683661,"name":"Jeremiah Johnson","username":"Johnsonjer","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/9d8465/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-07-18T14:05:58.115Z","cooked":"

What type of equipment do you have available?

I think it is beneficial to split training into two tracks: mechanical CAD/design and mechanical fabrication. There is an abundance of resources for mechanical CAD/design, like FRCDesign.org. However, mechanical fabrication will need to be tailored to the capabilities at your workspace. Importantly, training to design things that you can actually manufacture (or outsource to sponsors/etc) called “design for manufacture” needs to be considered.

For instance, we have quite a capable manufacturing facility and our kids tend to design parts for cutting our fiber laser for everything “because it’s fast and easy” despite being the incorrect approach. This fall they will be learning to use the lathe and vertical mill by making a spring-loaded tap follower. They’ll learn to read prints, use a caliper & micrometer, and assemble something, on top of basic mill and turn operations.

Don’t neglect designing and fabrication for electrical components, too.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-07-18T14:05:58.115Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":90,"readers_count":89,"score":58.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":500132,"topic_slug":"mechancal-training-ideas","display_username":"Jeremiah Johnson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gmzTG4RS4vI","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":5},{"url":"http://FRCDesign.org","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"FRCDesign.org","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":62712,"username":"Jow5119","name":"Jacob Waiser ","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jow5119/{size}/254314_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61884,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6419M, 648A"},"post_url":"/t/mechancal-training-ideas/500132/13","custom_user_title":"6419M, 648A","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3684275,"name":"","username":"saharsh","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/7993a0/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-07-18T20:19:18.399Z","cooked":"

What we did was that we used multiple “workshop” days, each day covering a different topic. Day 1 was basic tool use with heavy supervision (i.e. riveters, drills, small hand tools and simple tabletop machines). Day 2 helped introduce strategic design, where we told new students to think of ways to shoot crescendo notes. They would spend that time talking out their design ideas, drawing it out, etc. and in the end we made them come to a consensus. Day 3 was the start of the “capstone project,” which involved building the shooter, assigning different groups to different parts, such as the frame, power transfer, etc, and we would hand it over to the electrical and programming sub teams to wire it to an eboard and program it. Day 4 was showing off the final capstone projects and testing the shooters. Day 5 was a “crossover” day and involved switching sub teams for a day and getting “cross-trained” as it usually is helpful for mech students to know basic electrical concepts and vice-versa. This is what we do to give new students some experience in both mechanical/build and strategic design going into the season. Hope this helps.

In our case we split our design and mechanical fabrication subteams in terms of training so I’m looking at just ideas for fabrication (I should also clarify our mech team includes electrical too) but I will definitely talk to our design lead about some of the things you recommended! In terms of fabrication abilities and tools I’d hope to cover our team often uses the Miter saw, band saw, lathe, drill press, rivet gun, hand tap, and the common hand tools (drills, saws).
